comments.body: this should be a common function in basic.py (i think there is this one or the reverse there already)

Maybe it should be, but i don't see anything right off in basic.py that turns a character string into an int. I see something called pretty_bytes() in basic.py which does the opposite of what I need. It turns a number into a string with this format: '%.2f %s' % (float(size)/ limit, suffix)
this is already done by argspec when param is defined as boolean, all redundant
pretty sure this is specific to docker_common, especially where we drop in specific values for cert_path, cacert_path and key_path.
Could you please update `lib/ansible/utils/module_docs_fragments/docker.py` to mention these variables, see `lib/ansible/utils/module_docs_fragments/vmware.py` to an example

Yes, that would be a good idea. I guess we can get rid of the corresponding paragraph in the `notes:` section then.

@denraf Can you also update the documentation (in the docs fragment) for `cacert_path`, `cert_path` and `key_path`? They are a bit more tricky, since there the value of the env variable `DOCKER_CERT_PATH` is taken and modified.

comments.body:
Shouldn't `NEEDS_DOCKER_PY2` be `True` if the required version is `>=2.0` instead than `<2.0`?

```suggestion
        NEEDS_DOCKER_PY2 = (LooseVersion(min_docker_version) >= LooseVersion('2.0'))
```
Yes, you are right! Thanks for spotting this. I'll create a new PR for fixing this (since this was already merged).

Currently the module would suggest installing `docker` when `min_docker_version < LooseVersion(2.0)` and `docker` or `docker-py` otherwise.
These messages should be swapped, and would be by applying the suggestion above

comments.body: I recognize that this will be covered by the existing integration tests, but would it be worthwhile to add unit tests around this functionality? There's enough logic in here that I think it merits additional validation.
A very good point! I'll add something.

comments.body: Probably a good idea to add some examples of what data you expect result to contain here and also document warnings_key.  It will make the algorithm more readily understandable.

I'm still in the process of finding that out. The docker-py API is not very well documented, in fact the warnings I added are the only two which are documented. According to the daemon API documentation, some other endpoints also return warnings (though usually at most one warning), but in some cases these are not passed on by docker-py. Once I'll figure out some more I'll extend the original code...
